@graph.d3f:definition: Credential Hardening techniques modify system or network properties in order to protect system or network/domain credentials.
@graph.rdfs:label: Credential Hardening

d3f:CredentialHardening.d3f:definition: Credential Hardening techniques modify system or network properties in order to protect system or network/domain credentials.
d3f:CredentialHardening.rdfs:label: Credential Hardening

@graph.d3f:definition: Using biological measures in order to authenticate a user.
@graph.rdfs:label: Biometric Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Requiring a digital certificate in order to authenticate a user.
@graph.rdfs:label: Certificate-based Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: Persisting either a server's X509 certificate or their public key and comparing that to server's presented identity to allow for greater client confidence in the remote server's identity for SSL connections.
@graph.rdfs:label: Certificate Pinning

@graph.d3f:definition: Credential Hardening techniques modify system or network properties in order to protect system or network/domain credentials.
@graph.rdfs:label: Credential Hardening

@graph.d3f:definition: Limiting the transmission of a credential to a scoped set of relying parties.
@graph.rdfs:label: Credential Transmission Scoping

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting inter-domain trust by modifying domain configuration.
@graph.rdfs:label: Domain Trust Policy

@graph.d3f:definition: Requiring proof of two or more pieces of evidence in order to authenticate a user.
@graph.rdfs:label: Multi-factor Authentication

@graph.d3f:definition: A one-time password is valid for only one user authentication.
@graph.rdfs:label: One-time Password

@graph.d3f:definition: Modifying system configuration to increase password strength.
@graph.rdfs:label: Strong Password Policy

@graph.d3f:definition: Restricting a user account's access to resources.
@graph.rdfs:label: User Account Permissions
